questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and distension for the past 1 day. He has a prior history of diverticular disease. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan displayed below?

CT - computed tomography
questions.solution:
The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. A colonic perforation is the most likely diagnosis.

 

The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. In an elderly patient presenting with severe abdominal pain and distension, with a history of diverticulosis, a colonic perforation due to perforated diverticulitis is most likely. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

CT imaging is more sensitive and can detect even small amounts of gas in the peritoneal recesses.

Other options:

Option A: The interposition of the bowel, typically the colon, between the superior surface of the liver and the inferior surface of the right hemidiaphragm is denoted by the chilaiditi sign. This condition, known as pseudopneumoperitoneum, could potentially lead to unwarranted additional diagnostic procedures and treatment if misdiagnosed as pneumoperitoneum. Below is a CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Option B: Small bowel obstruction can also present with complaints of abdominal pain and distension. However, there would be an associated history of obstipation with multiple air-fluid levels on radiographic imaging and not pneumoperitoneum.

Option D: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum. Below is a CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A patient's gall bladder has the following appearance on MRI. What is the most likely interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the gallbladder is known as a Phrygian cap, which is a normal anatomical variant.

Phrygian cap refers to an anatomical variant of the gallbladder, where the gallbladder's fundus folds on itself or is separated from the body by a partial or complete septum. A true septum is uncommon and is usually an apparent septum due to the gallbladder wall folding. It is an incidental finding that may be seen on CT, MRI, or ultrasound. It causes no symptoms.

The Phrygian cap is named so, due to the resemblance of the ultrasonographic appearance to a hat or cap that is worn by the inhabitants of ancient Phrygia circa 1200 BC.

The image below shows a Phrygian cap:

 

Other options:

Option a: Cholangiocarcinoma is an adenocarcinoma originating from the bile duct. It is diagnosed based on a CT/MRI. Depending on the type of tumor, the findings may include capsular retraction, biliary dilatation, or wall thickening.

Option b: Choledochal cyst or biliary cystic disease commonly presents in childhood with pain, jaundice, and a right upper quadrant mass. MRCP is the preferred investigation.

Option c: Caroli's disease refers to a sporadic condition characterized by the formation of intrahepatic biliary cysts. USG /CT reveals the beaded appearance of the intrahepatic bile ducts with multiple cystic structures. It is characteristically associated with the central dot sign.

questions.text: Given below is the chest X-ray of an elderly male patient who presented with complaints of hemoptysis and breathlessness. Which of the following primary pathologies is unlikely to lead to this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
The radiographic image depicts the “cannonball appearance” of lungs with peripheral, rounded nodules of variable size scattered bilaterally. This is associated with pulmonary metastasis. Of all the options listed above, basal cell carcinoma of the skin is unlikely to lead to this finding.

For many malignancies, the lung is the most common site of metastasis. This occurs due to the hematogenous spread of the malignancy.  In adults, pulmonary metastases commonly originate from primary tumors in the breast, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, testes, head, and neck, as well as various bone and soft-tissue sarcomas. The detection of metastases is indicative of an advanced stage of the disease.

The simplest method for diagnosing lung metastases involves a basic posteroanterior (PA) and lateral chest X-ray. These radiographs are effective in identifying the majority of lung metastases that are larger than 1 cm in diameter. However, for enhanced sensitivity and the detection of smaller lesions, a CT scan is recommended.

Basal cell carcinoma is a skin cancer originating from basal cells and is the most prevalent type, often appearing on the face. Despite its common occurrence, the likelihood of distant metastasis is extremely rare. Therefore, it is improbable for basal cell carcinoma to be the cause of lung metastases in this patient.

questions.text: The image below shows X-rays of a patient with chronic osteomyelitis. The structure marked as ‘3’ in the given image denotes _______.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as '3' in the given image denotes sequestrum. Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.

In the given image, the marked structures are as follows:

  1. Involucrum is the thick sheath of periosteal new bone that surrounds the sequestrum. 
  2. Cloacae are openings in the involucrum that allow drainage of purulent and necrotic material out of the dead bone.
  3. Sequestrum is a piece of devitalized bone that has been separated from its surrounding bone during the process of necrosis.

questions.text:
As a radiology resident, you are asked to explain the radiological images given below to medical students with an appropriate clinical scenario. Some common clinical scenarios are listed below. Match the radiological images with their most likely clinical scenario.
  1. A 67-year-old male patient with chronic constipation
  2. A 46-year old woman with bloody diarrhea and weight loss for the last 2 years
  3. An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk
  4. A 55-year-old male patient with weight loss, constipation and anemia
questions.solution:
A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2 is the correct option among those given.

A 67-year-old male patient with chronic constipation could develop sigmoid volvulus which is identified by the coffee bean sign on an x-ray shown in A. 

A 46-year old woman with bloody diarrhea and weight loss for the last 2 years has ulcerative colitis that could be complicated by toxic megacolon identified by grossly dilated loops of bowel seen in D. 

An 8-month-old infant who has recently been weaned off breast milk has intussusception that is identified by a target sign on ultrasound seen in B. 

A 55-year-old male patient with weight loss, constipation, and anemia have colon cancer that is identified by apple-core lesion seen on barium studies as in C.

 

Image A (X-ray):

Sigmoid volvulus, most likely to be seen in an elderly male with chronic constipation leading to intestinal obstruction

Volvulus is a condition in which the bowel becomes twisted on its mesenteric axis, resulting in partial or complete obstruction of the bowel and impairment of its blood supply. The condition usually affects the colon, most commonly the sigmoid colon. Less frequently, the right colon and terminal ileum (referred to as cecal volvulus), the cecum alone and rarely, the transverse colon can also be affected.

Patients may present as acute or subacute intestinal obstruction with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation. The abdomen is generally markedly distended and tympanitic.

Plain abdominal X Rays typically reveal a markedly dilated sigmoid colon resembling a bent inner tube, with the apex in the right upper quadrant- Coffee bean sign or Bent inner tube sign. An air-fluid level may be visualized in the dilated loop of colon, and the rectum usually does not contain gas.

A contrast enema typically shows the pathognomonic bird’s beak deformity or bird of prey sign at the point of obstruction.

CT is not required for diagnosis but demonstrates a characteristic mesenteric whorl.

Treatment of the sigmoid volvulus involves appropriate resuscitation, followed by nonoperative decompression in most cases. Resection can be done as an elective procedure.

 

Image B (Ultrasound):

Target sign of intussusception, most likely seen in infants during the weaning period due to hypertrophy of the Payer's patches

USG image depicts target sign in intussusception. The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (Also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentry which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

 

Image C (Barium study X-ray):

Apple core lesion of colon cancer, most likely seen in elderly males with weight loss, anemia and constipation

Apple core sign/ napkin ring sign - Describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt “shouldered” margins resembling an apple core. The appearance is classically described on contrast enema studies and is almost always due to a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn's disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

 

Image D (X-ray):

Grossly dilated bowel loops of toxic megacolon, most likely seen in a middle-aged woman with blood diarrhea and weight loss

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon. The history of bloody diarrhea since many days is highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient of ulcerative colitis is highly suggestive of toxic megacolon.

A plain abdominal X-ray film may indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is particularly valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon.
Feces are present only in parts that are normal or only mildly inflamed. Mucosal islands can sometimes be seen. Small bowel loops in the right lower quadrant maybe a sign of severe disease.

questions.text: Which among the following demonstrates Water’s view?
questions.solution:
Image 1 demonstrates Waters' view.

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is taken such that the patient is erect and facing the detector with the chin raised. The orbitomeatal line should be at an angle of 37° from the receptor.

Structures seen in this view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if taken with the mouth open).
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa.

Indications:

  • Acute sinusitis
  • Facial fractures

Other options:

Image 2- Towne's view is an anteroposterior view with a 30° tilt from above and in front. The nuchal ridge should be touching the detector.

Image 3- Caldwell's view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with the nose and forehead touching the detector. The X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.

Image 4- Schuller's view is a lateral oblique view of the mastoid. The sagittal plane of the skull should be parallel to the film. X-ray beam is projected cephalocaudal at 30° to the sagittal plane.

The image below shows an X-ray taken in Waters' view:

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows splenic laceration. 

Splenic lacerations are linear low attenuation parenchymal defects and are almost always associated with haemoperitoneum.

The spleen is the visceral organ most commonly injured in blunt trauma abdomen. Severely ill patients may present with hypovolemic shock manifesting as tachycardia, hypotension, and pallor. A splenic rupture may not always be clinically apparent and spontaneous splenic rupture or pathological rupture can occur after minor trauma or insignificant events.

Investigation of choice in blunt trauma abdomen is CECT.

Splenic injury are currently classified into five grades based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) splenic injury scale (revised in 2018).

Management of splenic trauma:

  • Nonoperative management is preferred for stable grade I, II, or III splenic injuries.
  • Splenectomy is done for grade IV and V injuries.

CT showing splenic laceration and hematoma:

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has hearing difficulty in his right ear, with frequent episodes of tinnitus. Further clinical examination shows a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Given below is his brain MRI image. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI image are diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. The rollover phenomenon is seen in this condition.

When speech audiometry is done on this patient, it shows poor speech discrimination. A reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit is called the rollover phenomenon. It is seen in retrocochlear type of hearing loss, as with an acoustic neuroma.

Vestibular schwannoma or ‘acoustic neuroma’ are benign tumors that exhibit Schwann cell differentiation and arise from the vestibular division of the VIII nerve but rarely may arise from the cochlear division of the VIII nerve within the internal auditory canal.

  • Mostly seen in 40- 60 years and no sexual predilection.
  • Progressive unilateral hearing loss with tinnitus is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Vth cranial nerve is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved.
  • Other nerves involved are IX, X, and XI cranial nerves and may also cause displacement of the brainstem resulting in increased intracranial pressure.

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Other options:

The recruitment phenomenon refers to abnormal growth of loud sounds (sound is amplified in order to be heard better). A loud sound that is tolerable by a normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable. It is a feature of cochlear pathologies like Meniere's disease and presbycusis. 

Diplacusis is the discordance of sounds in which a single auditory stimulus of a particular frequency is heard at different pitches in both ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds produce vertigo due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

The recruitment phenomenon, diplacusis, and Tullio phenomenon are all seen in Meniere's disease.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and weight loss.  An X-ray abdomen done shows the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and X-ray showing the presence of calcification in the pancreas are suggestive of Chronic pancreatitis. 

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.

ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

Other tests that can be done are:

  • CECT
  • MRCP- chain of lakes appearance
  • MRI
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)

Option B: Plain radiograph of the gallbladder may show radiopaque gallstones in only 10% of patients. Rarely, the center of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign. Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. They appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder.

Option C: Sarcoidosis affects the kidneys and sometimes may even end in kidney failure. Symptoms of kidney problems include inflammation, the formation of sarcoid “granulomas” in the kidney, and the formation of kidney stones made of calcium.

Option D: A patient with renal calculi presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. An erect abdominal X-ray showing staghorn calculus is shown below.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given image?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows Bennett's fracture. 

Bennett fracture is a fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone which extends into the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. This intra-articular fracture is the most common type of fracture of the thumb and is nearly always accompanied by some degree of subluxation or frank dislocation of the carpometacarpal joint. 

Radiographic features:

  • Two-piece fracture of the 1st metacarpal
  • Intraarticular extension
  • Dorsolateral displacement
  • The lateral pull of the 1st metacarpal shaft by abductor pollicis longus

Barton's fracture:

The dislocation of the radiocarpal joint is the hallmark of Barton's fracture.

The radiographic findings are the following:

  • Comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal radius
  • Volar rim maintains a relationship with the carpus and both are displaced proximally
  • Fracture of the radial styloid process with loss of radial inclination 

The image below shows Barton's fracture:

A Colles' fracture is a type of fracture of the distal forearm, with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. The following image shows a Colle's fracture 

A Smith's fracture, also sometimes known as a reverse Colles' fracture or Goyrand-Smith's, is a fracture of the distal radius. Here there is a forward displacement of the distal fragment.

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. She was unable to feed the baby as it choked on the milk. She also noticed the baby's abdomen appeared distended. Vesicular breath sounds in bilateral lung fields and abdominal distension were noted on examination. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.


Other options:

Option A - Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B - Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with episodes of intermittent right upper abdominal pain for the past few months. She underwent cholecystectomy a year back. Investigations showed elevated AST and ALT levels and imaging revealed a dilated common bile duct with prolonged biliary drainage time. What is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?

AST - Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT - Alanine aminotransferase
HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid
ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with manometry of the biliary and pancreatic sphincters is the gold standard for its diagnosis.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is characterized by abdominal pain, biliary or pancreatic duct dilatation due to abnormal function of the sphincter of Oddi.

Clinical types include biliary and pancreatic SOD.

Biliary type presents with biliary pain, raised liver enzymes, and/or dilation of the bile duct and/or evidence of delayed emptying on biliary imaging. It should be excluded in patients with post-cholecystectomy syndrome. Pancreatic SOD presents as recurrent episodes of unexplained acute pancreatitis.

CT and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can demonstrate dilatation of the biliary and pancreatic ducts. MRCP with intravenous secretin injection demonstrates dilatation of the pancreatic duct due to increased sphincter pressures. Endoscopic ultrasound can also be used. HIDA scan will show delayed biliary transit.

The gold standard investigation is ERCP with manometry and is indicated in disabling pain, when noninvasive investigations fail to demonstrate structural abnormalities and when conservative therapy fails. Basal sphincter pressure higher than 40 mm Hg is suggestive of SOD.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. It involves the use of a side-viewing endoscope which is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It can be a therapeutic and diagnostic modality specifically for viewing the distal biliary tree. The most common indication for therapeutic ERCP is the relief of biliary obstruction due to gallstone disease and benign or malignant biliary strictures.  

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the best confirmatory test of the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Manometry is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a barium swallow, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy is usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 3 year old boy playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in breathing  for the last few hours.  The X-ray image is given below. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Urgent endoscopy and removal of foreign body
Remove the foreign body within 2 hours

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in breathing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin and the most appropriate management is urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body. 

The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck showing the flat surface and edge of the coin respectively. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested by children. 

Initial symptoms are choking, gagging, and coughing followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat. Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea are seen if esophageal foreign body impinges on the larynx or tracheal wall.

Imaging with AP views of chest, neck, and abdominal x-rays and lateral views of chest and neck x-rays should be done. Chest CT is warranted if airway perforation is suspected.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic patients with blunt objects/coin ingestion can be observed for up to 24 hours to wait for the passage of the coin into the stomach (option A)
  • Immediate endoscopic visualization must be done in symptomatic patients. Flexible endoscopy with suitable grasping forceps is used to remove the foreign bodies. 
  • Button batteries should be removed within 2 hours (Option C) since they can induce a mucosal injury as early as one hr and can invade all the layers within 4 hrs. They can resemble a coin but are differentiated by the double halo on the X-ray.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve.

CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

The tram-track sign is useful in the differentiation between optic nerve meningioma and optic nerve gliomas.

CT may be also useful in detecting calcification within the meningioma which is specific to optic nerve meningioma and not seen in optic nerve glioma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with pain and stiffness in her hands for 1 year. The joints involved were the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints were spared. Her X-ray is shown below. The given finding is classically seen in _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows a gull-wing appearance/ seagull erosions/ saw-tooth appearance, which is classically seen in erosive osteoarthritis (OA) of the hand.

In OA of the hand, the joints involved are the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP), and the first carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb), while the wrist, elbow, and ankle are usually spared.

The nodules palpable in the DIP are called Heberden’s nodes, while those palpable in the PIP are called Bouchard’s nodes.

The image given below shows Heberden's nodes and Bouchard's nodes.

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: Ethmoidal bullectomy would entail the removal of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the osteomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and the same is removed in ethmoidal bullectomy.

This step should be performed carefully so as to avoid damage to the medial orbital wall, skull base, or anterior ethmoidal artery.

The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy. Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to approach the middle meatus.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

The following image gives an explanation of these structures.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis, refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of fronto-ethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male undergoes a diagnostic work-up for backache; his X-ray is given below. What is the most common ocular manifestation that you would expect to see in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows bamboo spine, which is seen in ankylosing spondylitis. The most common ocular condition in ankylosing spondylitis is anterior uveitis. It is also the most common extraarticular manifestation in ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints commonly seen in young males. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker. The progressive inflammatory granulation tissue in the spine in the paravertebral connective tissue leads to the bamboo spine.

Other extra-articular manifestations of AS:

  • Ocular: Iritis, conjunctivitis (reactive arthritis)
  • Cardiovascular: Valvular heart disease, aortitis, heart block
  • Neurologic: C1-C2 subluxation, cauda equina syndrome
  • GIT: Colitis, inflammatory bowel disease
  • Respiratory: Restrictive lung disease, upper lobe fibrosis

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Insidious in onset
  • Morning stiffness 
  • Symptoms begin early at the age of <40 years
  • Improvement with exercise
  • Persistence for more than three months 

Examination findings:

There is a loss of normal lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion. Other findings :

  • Positive Fleche's test - It is done to assess cervical spine involvement. The patient is asked to touch the wall with the back of the head without raising the chin.
  • Positive tests for sacroiliac joint involvement such as the pump-handle test, pelvic compression test, and Fabre’s test.
  • Schober’s test: It is used to detect reduced flexion of the spine. The test involves marking two points—one 10 cm above and one 5 cm below the level of the lumbosacral junction of the patient. The patient is then asked to bend forward, and the distance between the two points is measured. This distance normally increases by ≥5 cm. An increase of <4 cm indicates reduced flexion.

In the image below, the distance increases by 5 cm which is normal.

questions.text: A pet shop owner presented with upper abdominal discomfort. On examination, mild tenderness is found in the right hypochondrium. USG revealed a cyst with the finding given in the image below. According to WHO classification, this cyst belongs to which of the following type?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the USG showing a cyst with detached membranes(Water Lily sign) are suggestive of a hydatid cyst. Cyst with detached membranes is classified as CE-3 according to the WHO classification. 

WHO classification of hydatid cyst

Stage

 Description

CL (cystic lesion)

Unilocular anechoic cystic lesion without internal echoes or septations

CE (cystic echinococcosis) 1

Uniformly anechoic cyst with fine internal echoes that represent protoscolices after rupturing of a vesicle, called ‘hydatid sand’

CE 2

Cyst with internal septation representing the walls of the daughter cyst described as multivesicular, honeycomb, cartwheel, or rosette formation

CE 3
(transitional stage) description of daughter cyst

3A: daughter cysts with detached laminated membrane(Water lily sign)

3B- daughter cysts inside a solid matrix

CE 4(inactive/degenerative)

Daughter cysts can no longer be seen.

A mixture of hypoechoic and hyperechoic features – like a bag of wool

CE 5

(inactive/degenerative)

  

Calcification of the wall; either partial or complete

Hydatid Cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species(dog tapeworm ). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. Diagnosis is suggested by the finding of a multiloculated cyst on ultrasound and is further supported by the finding of a floating membrane within the cysts on a CT scan. Active cysts contain a large number of smaller daughter cysts (multi-vesicular rosette-like cystic lesions with daughter cysts) which is characteristic of hydatid cysts of the liver.

The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below)

The serpent sign is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst, on CT imaging.

A ball of wool sign is seen on ultrasound when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst, as seen below.

The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.
